results.title: Nature's complete food
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
In the rainforests of Central America grows a most unusual tree. It produces nature’s most complete food…the avocado. The avocado tree grows quite happily in temperate Australia, but it doesn’t always produce good crops. CSIRO scientist Dr Margaret Sedgley has been finding out why. The avocado’s erratic behaviour seems due to adverse temperatures. CSIRO’s research has focused on the two most important varieties - smooth-skinned Fuerte, and rough-skinned hass. North-western Victoria is an important new area for avocado growing. Here the researchers are looking at another problem. Irrigation water from the Murray may cause salt damage to trees at certain times of the year. Whether it’s possible to solve some of these problems of growing avocados in Australian conditions, only time and further research will tell.

results.title: Moss: nature's metal detector
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Reports on the natural ability of Sphagnum moss to measure air-borne particles of heavy metals.

results.title: Molecules in outer space
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Radio astronomers scan the skies with the giant Parkes radio telescope in search of radio signals from molecules. They are looking for evidence pointing to the existence of life in space or to the conditions under which life forms could develop.

results.title: Lucerne: a stronger shade of green
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Lucerne is one of the richest feed crops grown for livestock and an important source of nitrogen for the soil. In 1977 varieties of aphids began attacking this vital crop. This film shows programs begun by the CSIRO to counter the aphid attacks.

results.title: Looking at lobsters
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Describes the life cycle of the rock lobster and shows its remarkable moulting behaviour. Notes the work of marine biologists from the CSIRO and WA Department of Fisheries in learning of the factors controlling its population levels, which are crucial to the maintenance of exports.

results.title: Leucaena: forage for the north
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Examines research by CSIRO’s Division of Tropical Crops and Pastures into leucaena, a legume native to Mexico, and its application to beef production in Northern Australia.

results.title: Landscapes from space
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Landsat data being processed by CSIRO are revealing a new picture of mineral areas, the environment, agriculture and land use planning in Western Australia.

results.title: In a nutshell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Australian gum trees are of considerable economic importance in various parts of the world. This demand is met by providing gum seeds to the countries that want our nuts.
